desc: To allot something means to give it to someone.
exam: The coach allotted each team five minutes to prepare a strategy.

desc: To appall means to horrify, shock, or disgust someone.
exam: The boy was appalled when he saw the accident.

desc: A cache is a hiding place for valuable things.
exam: The pirates kept their jewelry in a cache hidden in a cave.

desc: Convenience is a state of being able to do something with little effort.
exam: The Internet allows consumers to shop at their own convenience.

desc: A dearth is an amount or supply which is not large enough.
exam: There is a dearth of money in my bank account. I can’t afford a new car.

desc: If a thing you do is deliberate, you intend to do it.
exam: She made a deliberate effort to save money each month.

desc: When something is dire, it is terrible and very serious.
exam: The tornado created a dire situation for the small town.

desc: To elapse means to pass, as in seconds, minutes, or hours.
exam: A few seconds must elapse before you can take another picture.

desc: Empathy is sharing or understanding another person’s feelings.
exam: The caring nurse had empathy for her patients.

desc: When something is fanciful, it is unusual or unrealistic.
exam: The girl had fanciful ideas about doing well in school without studying.

desc: To gripe means to complain constantly.
exam: Lawrence always gripes when he has to do chores.

desc: When something is grueling, it is very hard to do.
exam: The climber faced the grueling task of reaching the top of the steep mountain.

desc: When something is mundane, it is boring, common, or ordinary.
exam: The man had the mundane chore of raking thousands of leaves into piles.

desc: To opt is to make a choice, especially when deciding in favor of something.
exam: My brother likes chocolate ice cream, but I always opt for vanilla.

desc: Outrage is a very strong emotion of anger or shock.
exam: Tommy was feeling outrage when his parents said he couldn’t go to the dance.

desc: When an amount of something is paltry, it is very small.
exam: The poor man had a paltry sum of money.

desc: To rectify something means to correct it.
exam: I quickly rectified the spelling mistakes that I had on my essay.

desc: When someone is resourceful, they are good at dealing with hard situations.
exam: After his boat sunk, Matt was resourceful enough to build a raft.

desc: Sustenance is food and water needed to keep a person, animal, or plant alive.
exam: Without the proper sustenance, the man will starve.

desc: When something is tedious, it is long, frustrating, and boring.
exam: His job involved a lot of tedious typing, filing, and organizing.

desc: An abbey is a house or group of houses where monks or nuns live.
exam: When the monk returned to the abbey, he went immediately to his bedroom.

desc: If something is abundant, then it is available in large quantities.
exam: Cakes, cookies, and candy were so abundant that the child was very happy.

desc: To adjoin something means to be next to or attached to something else.
exam: She can listen to her brother’s conversations because her room adjoins his.

desc: If something is ample, then it is enough or more than enough.
exam: There was an ample supply of oats to feed the horses.

desc: If a place is arid, then it is hot and dry and gets very little or no rain.
exam: Not many plants grow in the arid desert.

desc: A cathedral is an important and often large and beautifully built church.
exam: The large cathedral is full of people on Sunday mornings.

desc: To deprive someone of something means to not let them have it.
exam: Because the child was bad, she was deprived of her dessert after dinner.

desc: A drought is a long period of time in which little or no rain falls.
exam: After three months of drought, the vegetation and trees started dying.

desc: If someone is eligible, then they are permitted to do or have something.
exam: Only people who bought tickets were eligible to win a prize.

desc: To fast means to go without food or drink for a period of time.
exam: In her religion, they fast for five days and then have a big feast.

desc: To grumble means to complain.
exam: He grumbled about having to work late on Friday.

desc: If someone goes inland, they travel into the center of a country or land.
exam: The river curved inland near the campground.

desc: Moisture is small drops of water in the air or on a surface.
exam: If you breathe on a window, moisture from your breath collects on the glass.

desc: If something happens nonetheless, then it occurs despite some other thing.
exam: She tried to keep the dog out of the mud, but it got dirty nonetheless.

desc: An oath is a formal, often public, promise.
exam: Judges must take an oath to be fair to everyone in court.

desc: A prairie is a large flat area of grassland.
exam: The prairie was perfect for a farm because there were hills and trees.

desc: If something is ragged, then it is old, torn, and falling apart.
exam: They could see his toes through the holes in his ragged shoes.

desc: If an area of land is rugged, then it is rocky and difficult to travel through.
exam: Their car couldn’t make it far along the rugged roads.

desc: If something is scarce, then it is in a very small amount.
exam: When gasoline was scarce, we rode our bikes, instead of driving, to school.

desc: To speculate means to guess about something.
exam: My sister looked at the sky and speculated that it would rain tomorrow.

desc: If something is analytic, it is related to logic and reasoning.
exam: The analytic article criticized the new plan and presented one of its own.

desc: To assert a fact or belief means to state it with confidence.
exam: He asserted that his mother’s cooking was better than his best friend’s.

desc: A bachelor is an unmarried man.
exam: Since he was a bachelor, Jason did his shopping by himself.

desc: Calculus is an advanced type of mathematics.
exam: By using calculus, scientists determined small changes in the stars’ brightness.

desc: If something is celestial, it is related to the sky or to outer space.
exam: Comets are celestial objects that are rarely seen.

desc: If something is cognitive, it is related to learning and knowing things.
exam: After her physical examination, her cognitive strengths were tested.

desc: A collision is the act of two things hitting into each another.
exam: The collision between the two cars created a loud noise.

desc: If someone is competent, they are able to think or act successfully.
exam: Competent employees are much better than unknowledgeable ones.

desc: A diploma is a certificate proving that someone has completed their studies.
exam: After four years of college, Mary finally had a diploma.

desc: To excel at a subject or activity means to be very good at it.
exam: Jenny excels at playing the piano.

desc: Geology is the study of the Earth’s natural structures and how they change.
exam: Because he studied geology, he knew how the mountains were formed.

desc: To harness something means to control and use it, usually to make energy.
exam: The sails harness the wind in order to move.

desc: An intellect is a person’s ability to understand things easily.
exam: She was known for her quick and strong intellect as well as her beauty.

desc: If someone is keen, they are intelligent.
exam: Only the keenest of students could have solved that math problem.

desc: Mythology is a group of stories from a particular country or region.
exam: Egyptian mythology was the basis for a religion.

desc: Physiology is the study of the various parts of living things.
exam: His work in physiology helped him understand how the human body works.

desc: If something is radioactive, then it lets out, or is related to, radiation.
exam: Radioactive materials can be very bad for anyone’s health.

desc: Relativity is a set of ideas about time and space developed by Albert Einstein.
exam: Relativity teaches that light travels at the same speed in the universe.

desc: Sociology is the study of human society, its organizations, and problems.
exam: Sociology teaches that people’s problems are a result of their society.

desc: If something is theoretical, it is based on theory rather than experience.
exam: His conclusion was only theoretical and not meant to be publicized.

desc: An administrator is a person who controls a business, company, or organization.
exam: Everyone in the store did whatever the administrator asked them to do.

desc: If someone is affluent, they are wealthy.
exam: People in the city are usually more affluent than people in the country.

desc: To audit means to inspect financial records from a person or business.
exam: The government usually audits companies that report lower than usual incomes.

desc: To automate a company means to install machines or computers to do the work.
exam: When the bank automated, it started installing ATM machines.

desc: To bribe someone means to illegally persuade them for a favor with money.
exam: The judge was bribed so that she would set the suspect free.

desc: If someone is corrupt, they break the law for money or fame.
exam: The corrupt policemen didn’t arrest the man because he gave them money.

desc: To dispose of something means to get rid of it.
exam: He disposed of the can by throwing it into the recycle bin.

desc: A headquarters is a building where the bosses of a company work.
exam: He drove the long route to headquarters because it was a nice day.

desc: An incentive is what makes a person want to do something.
exam: The chance of winning a prize was incentive to get people to play the game.

desc: An infrastructure is a collection of services needed to run a society or business.
exam: Power lines are important parts of a city’s infrastructure.

desc: To legislate means to make laws.
exam: Senators have to legislate fairly, so most people will enjoy the benefits.

desc: If something is legitimate, then it is acceptable according to the law.
exam: She found a legitimate plan to raise extra funds for her vacation.

desc: To manipulate something means to skillfully or unfairly control or affect it.
exam: The Dr. manipulated the data to make it look like the cure was working.

desc: Merchandise is goods ready to be purchased or sold.
exam: The store added more merchandise because there were more shoppers.

desc: Retail is the activity of selling goods to the public, often for personal use.
exam: Though cheap to make, once a t-shirt reaches retail, it costs ten times as much.

desc: Revenue is the income made by a company.
exam: The new products really increased the business’s monthly revenue.

desc: Rubbish is trash or waste.
exam: The floor around the garbage can was covered with all kinds of rubbish.

desc: A subsidy is money given by the government to companies to assist them.
exam: The official gave the company a subsidy, so it could open two new factories.

desc: A transaction is an act of buying or selling something.
exam: Because the clerk was new at the job, the simple transaction took a long time.

desc: To violate a law, rule, or agreement means to break it.
exam: I was given a ticket because the policeman said I violated the speed limit.

desc: To assess something means to judge the structure, purpose, or quality of it.
exam: She assessed the condition of the toy car before buying it.

desc: To astonish someone means to greatly surprise them.
exam: The amount of people that came to her party astonished her.

desc: To commence something means to begin it.
exam: His speech commenced with a “thankyou” to all who had helped him succeed.

desc: The essence of something is its important qualities or basic characteristics.
exam: The essence of the argument was that both sides felt they had lost money.

desc: To extract something means to remove it.
exam: The dentist extracted the woman’s damaged tooth and put in a fake one.

desc: If something is fabulous, it is extremely good.
exam: This strawberry is the best I’ve ever had. It’s fabulous.

desc: Haste is speed in movement or action.
exam: In order to get to the meeting in time, he proceeds with haste.

desc: An impulse is a sudden thoughtless urge to do something.
exam: Because of the scary noise, she had an impulse to run somewhere and hide.

desc: Latter describes something last in a series or the second choice of two things.
exam: In the latter minutes of the game, the visitors scored the winning goal.

desc: A molecule is the smallest basic unit that makes up a physical substance.
exam: A tiny drop of water is made up of thousands of molecules of water.

desc: If something is ongoing, then it is still happening or still growing.
exam: The development of plants is ongoing because it takes time for them to mature.

desc: If something is pharmaceutical, then it is related to the development of drugs.
exam: Pharmaceutical companies discover new cures to illnesses all the time.

desc: If someone is precise, then they are exact and careful about their work.
exam: The builder was very precise about where he placed the nails.

desc: Proximity is closeness in time, space, or relationships.
exam: All the trees in the proximity of the beach had been cut down.

desc: Publicity is public attention given to someone or something by the media.
exam: She received a lot of publicity after her performance in the film.

desc: A remedy is a cure for a disease, argument, or problem.
exam: A good remedy for a headache is an aspirin and a glass of water.

desc: The significance of something is the quality that makes it important.
exam: The significance of the snowy weather was that we didn’t have to go to school.

desc: If something is subsequent, then it comes after something else in time.
exam: The flood and the subsequent rescue of those caught in the flood were on TV.

desc: If something is synthetic, then it is made to be like something natural.
exam: Clothing made out of synthetic fabrics is very effective at keeping people warm.

desc: If something is terminal, then it causes or results in death.
exam: Since his condition was not terminal, he felt a great sense of relief.

desc: The altitude of a place is its height above sea level.
exam: The air was thin at such a high altitude on the mountain.

desc: A coastline is the outline of a country’s coast.
exam: He noticed that most of the cities in Australia are on the coastline.

desc: To deter means to prevent or discourage someone from doing something.
exam: Icy roads deter people from driving their cars.

desc: To devise something means to have an idea or plan about it in the mind.
exam: The thieves devised a plan to steal the diamonds.

desc: Expertise is the knowledge and skills to do something well.
exam: John has a lot of advertising expertise. He can sell anything!

desc: A fracture is a crack or break in something.
exam: Don’t stand on that teg because there is a fracture. It might get worse.

desc: To impair something means to damage it or make it worse.
exam: Drinking coffee impairs my ability to go to sleep.

desc: To implement something means to ensure that what has been planned is done.
exam: The school decided to implement a new teaching strategy.

desc: If something is indigenous, it is originally from, or native to, a place.
exam: Tomatoes are indigenous to the Americas.

desc: Insight is a deep and accurate understanding of something.
exam: The physics textbook gave the student new insight about gravity.

desc: A limb is a large branch on a tree.
exam: The monkey sat on the tree limb and enjoyed a piece of fruit.

desc: A migraine is a painful headache that makes one feel sick.
exam: My sister gets a migraine every time she has a lot of stress.

desc: Optimism is the feeling of being hopeful about the future or success of something.
exam: The mother had optimism about her children’s futures.

desc: When something is peculiar, it is strange, sometimes in a bad way.
exam: That peculiar smell coming from the kitchen reminds me of rotten eggs.

desc: When a person is proficient at something, they can do it well.
exam: Secretaries are proficient at typing quickly.

desc: A quest is a long and difficult search for something.
exam: The treasure hunter went on a quest to find an ancient gold necklace.

desc: A ridge is a long, narrow piece of raised land.
exam: The brown bear walked along the edge of the mountain ridge.

desc: A spouse is the person to whom someone is married.
exam: I live in a home with my spouse and our two children.

desc: To thrust means to push or move something quickly with a lot of force.
exam: The boxer thrust his fist into the punching bag.

desc: To tolerate something means to be able to accept it even when it is unpleasant.
exam: When you are in a hurry, it can be hard to tolerate traffic signals.

desc: If a plant or animal is aquatic, it lives or grows in water.
exam: The dolphin is an aquatic mammal.

desc: The biosphere is the earth’s surface and atmosphere where there are living things.
exam: Birds, trees, and worms all thrive in the biosphere.

desc: When something is bizarre, it is very strange.
exam: My bizarre dreams make no sense to me when I am awake.

desc: Celsius is a scale for measuring temperature.
exam: Water freezes at zero degrees Celsius.

desc: If something is coarse, that means it has a rough texture.
exam: The coarse sweater made my skin itch.

desc: A companion is a person that someone spends a lot of time with.
exam: I always walk to school with my companion Frank.

desc: To digest means to swallow food and pass it through the body.
exam: Allow some time for food to be digested before going swimming.

desc: The duration of an event is the time during which it happens.
exam: The girls watched television for the duration of the evening.

desc: Ecology is the study of the environment and living things.
exam: We study ecology to learn how to help improve the Earth.

desc: A feat is an impressive or difficult achievement or action.
exam: The elephant’s standing up on one leg was a feat.

desc: If something is infinite, it has no limit or end.
exam: Many scientists believe that the universe is infinite.

desc: The nucleus is the central part of an atom or cell.
exam: The nucleus is made up of many tiny particles.

desc: A parasite is a tiny animal or plant that attaches to another animal to get food.
exam: The sick dog was covered in parasites.

desc: When something is prominent, it is important and well known.
exam: Queen Victoria was a prominent person in history.

desc: When something is repetitive, it is repeated many times and becomes boring.
exam: Working on an assembly line making cars every day is a repetitive job.

desc: If something is reproductive, it has to do with a living thing producing young.
exam: The reproductive system of a plant is simple.

desc: When a place is temperate, it never gets too hot or cold.
exam: In Peru, the weather is temperate and rarely gets too hot or cold.

desc: Tolerance is the ability to accept something painful or unpleasant.
exam: Boxers have a high tolerance for pain.

desc: To undergo an action means to have it happen to you.
exam: The cancer patient undergoes treatments twice a week. gous

desc: When someone is vulnerable, they are weak and without protection.
exam: He felt very vulnerable when he was stranded in the desert.

desc: If someone is adept at something, they are very good at doing it.
exam: The carpenter is very adept at building houses.

desc: If land is barren, it has no plants growing on it.
exam: People cannot farm in barren lands.

desc: If something is ceramic, it is made of baked clay.
exam: The house’s roof was made of ceramic tiles.

desc: If something is culinary, it is related to cooking.
exam: I gained culinary skills after working in a restaurant for many years.

desc: If something is dense, it has a lot of things close together.
exam: I easily became lost in the dense forest.

desc: Dignity is the ability to be calm and worthy of respect.
exam: When his company went out of business, he faced it with dignity.

desc: To dominate someone or something is to control them.
exam: The loud man dominated the conversation.

desc: If something is edible, you can eat it.
exam: We learn about edible plants when we go camping.

desc: If someone is hostile, they are angry and unfriendly.
exam: We were happy to move away from our hostile neighbor.

desc: Your intake of food is the amount of food you take into your body.
exam: The doctor said I needed to increase my intake of fruits and vegetables.

desc: If someone does something likewise, they do the same thing as someone else.
exam: If Joe is staying away from school to go swimming, I want to do likewise.

desc: Malnutrition is the condition of not getting enough nutrients.
exam: After eating only a meager amount of food, she suffered from malnutrition.

desc: Medication is medicine or drugs given to people who are sick.
exam: The doctor gave me medication to treat my illness.

desc: A misconception is a wrong idea about something.
exam: People once believed the misconception that the Earth is flat.

desc: If something is obscure, it is not well-known.
exam: The old man travels the world in search of obscure books.

desc: To oppress someone means to rule over them in a cruel and unfair way.
exam: Free speech had been oppressed in his country.

desc: To peel fruits and vegetables is to remove their skin.
exam: We peeled the apple before eating it.

desc: A prescription is permission from a doctor to get medicine.
exam: The doctor gave me a prescription for my medication.

desc: A respirator is a machine that helps weak or sick people breathe.
exam: The man needed a respirator to breathe.

desc: To strive is to struggle to achieve something.
exam: People who strive to succeed often do.

desc: If something is archaic, it is very old or outdated.
exam: To be competitive, we must update our archaic equipment.

desc: If someone is benevolent, they are kind and generous.
exam: My father was a benevolent man and gave lots of money to charity.

desc: Brass is a metal that is used to make musical instruments and ornaments.
exam: Brass is used to make musical instruments like trumpets.

desc: Capitalism is an economic system where private companies make goods for profit.
exam: Most industries in the world today are based on capitalism.

desc: A component is a part of a larger machine.
exam: Computers have many different components, so they are complicated to build.

desc: Dependence is a situation in which somebody relies on something else.
exam: Young children have a dependence on their parents.

desc: To diminish means to reduce or get smaller.
exam: As the economy got worse, my savings diminished.

desc: A drawback is a disadvantage.
exam: The drawback of having a car is that it is very expensive to maintain.

desc: A fad is something that is popular for a short time.
exam: The hula hoop was a fad for a few years, but it soon lost its popularity.

desc: To impose means to interrupt or force your ideas on other people.
exam: He imposes on his wife every morning by expecting her to make breakfast.

desc: Managerial describes something related to a manager or management.
exam: Nancy has a managerial position at the bank.

desc: If something is medieval, it comes from the period between 650 and 1500 CE.
exam: We visited a castle that was built during medieval times.

desc: If something is obsolete, it is not used anymore because something better exists.
exam: Since computers became inexpensive, typewriters have become obsolete.

desc: A peninsula is a large piece of land that is surrounded by the sea on three sides.
exam: The state of Florida is an example of a peninsula.

desc: If a person has prestige, people admire or respect them.
exam: The young actress gained much prestige after she won an award.

desc: A proportion is an amount that shows the link between the parts and the whole.
exam: Only a small proportion of the people in this town actually work here.

desc: If something is radical, it is very new or different.
exam: The president is planning to make some radical changes to the law.

desc: To refute something means to prove that it is false or incorrect.
exam: The bank manager has refuted the claims that he lied to his customers.

desc: If something is spectacular, it looks or sounds very impressive.
exam: There was a spectacular fireworks display in the park at New Year.

desc: To weave means to make cloth using horizontal and vertical threads.
exam: We saw a woman weave a blanket on our vacation to South America.

desc: An accountant is a person whose job is to keep financial accounts.
exam: The accountant helped me keep track of my money.

desc: A capitalist is a business person who invests in trade and industry for profit.
exam: The capitalist invested in a factory that made wheat into cereal.

desc: Contempt is the feeling of having no respect for something.
exam: The judge had contempt for the wicked criminal.

desc: To dedicate oneself to something means to put a lot of time and effort into it.
exam: The nun dedicated herself to helping people in need.

desc: A ditch is a narrow hole cut into the ground by a road or a field.
exam: When the car slid off of the road, it fell into the ditch.

desc: An enterprise is a company or business.
exam: My father owns an advertising enterprise.

desc: When something is exquisite, it is very beautiful or pleasant.
exam: The artist made exquisite watercolor paintings.

desc: To finance someone or something means to provide money for them.
exam: The government financed the scientist’s experiments with new weapons.

desc: When someone is indifferent toward something, they have a lack of interest in it.
exam: Lisa is indifferent toward school. She doesn’t care what her final grades are.

desc: To irrigate means to supply water to land so that crops can grow.
exam: In dry climates, it is important to irrigate fields of crops.

desc: To maximize something is to make it as great in amount, size, or importance.
exam: You should exercise regularly to maximize a healthy lifestyle.

desc: When something is monetary, it relates to money.
exam: A strong monetary policy is important for a country to be successful.

desc: A precaution is an action that is meant to stop something bad from happening.
exam: Asa precaution, you should put on a heavy coat before going out in cold weather.

desc: Preliminary describes something that happens before a more important event.
exam: The runners must do well in the preliminary races to qualify for the final race.

desc: To saturate something means to completely soak it with a liquid.
exam: The sponge was saturated with soapy water and dripped all over the floor.

desc: The simplicity of something is the fact that it is easy to do or understand.
exam: We were able to find the house thanks to the simplicity of the directions.

desc: To sow seeds means to plant them in the ground.
exam: He always sows his garden seeds in the springtime.

desc: Soy is a food made from soybeans, such as flour or butter.
exam: Soy can be made into tofu, sauce, and also milk.

desc: A spade is a tool used for digging.
exam: The gardener used her spade to make a hole for the seed.

desc: When something is upcoming, that means it will happen in the near future.
exam: The kids were worried about their upcoming exam.

desc: When a bad thing is acute, it is very severe and intense.
exam: When she fell out of the tree, the girl felt an acute pain in her arm.

desc: Aggression is behavior that is mean or violent to others.
exam: The problem was only made worse by Mark’s aggression.

desc: A banquet is a grand formal dinner.
exam: Both families brought a lot of food for the wedding banquet.

desc: A biography is an account of someone’s life that is written by someone else.
exam: We read a biography about Charles Darwin in science class.

desc: To boost something means to increase or improve it.
exam: Lowering prices boosts customers’ interest in shopping.

desc: To clap means to hit one’s hands together to express pleasure or get attention.
exam: After the speech, everyone in the crowd clapped their hands for the speaker.

desc: To compel someone to do something means to force them to do it.
exam: Traffic signs compel drivers to drive safely.

desc: The dominance of a person is their state of being more powerful than others.
exam: Large gorillas hit their chests to express their dominance over others.

desc: When something is gorgeous, it is very pleasing and attractive.
exam: The girl picked out a gorgeous dress to wear to the dance.

desc: When something is inevitable, it is certain to happen or cannot be avoided.
exam: It is inevitable that the days will get longer in the summer.

desc: A legacy is an effect that exists because of a person or thing in the past.
exam: The legacy of the ancient Egyptians can be seen in their monuments.

desc: A masterpiece is a very good painting, novel, movie, or other work of art.
exam: The Arc de Triomphe is considered a masterpiece in the world of architecture.

desc: If there are multiple things, there are many of them.
exam: When the stunt went wrong, the man suffered multiple injuries.

desc: To narrate a story means to write about it or read it aloud.
exam: This story was written by John, but Aaron is narrating it to the crowd.

desc: When something is notorious, it is well-known because of something bad.
exam: This area of town is notorious for gang activity.

desc: When something is outdated, it is old and no longer useful in modern time.
exam: Tape players are becoming outdated because of digital music.

desc: When a thing is talked about overall, the whole thing is considered.
exam: Overall, the party was a huge success.

desc: A partiality is a tendency to prefer one thing to another.
exam: She has a partiality for walking to school instead of driving.

desc: When an act is spontaneous, it is not planned. It happens suddenly.
exam: My wife made a spontaneous decision to buy a new sofa while I was at work.

desc: A virtue is a good quality or way of behaving.
exam: My best virtue is forgiveness.

desc: Anthropology is the study of people, society, and culture.
exam: In anthropology class, I learned about simple tools that ancient cultures used.

desc: To applaud means to clap in order to show approval.
exam: Everyone cheered and applauded Manny’s efforts.

desc: To appoint someone to a job means to give the job to them.
exam: Two students were appointed to help the scientists with their research.

desc: When things are compatible, they work well or exist together successfully.
exam: Jan and Fred are too different. They will never be compatible.

desc: Competence is the ability to do something well or effectively.
exam: The job was easy because the group had enough competence to do it well.

desc: To confer with someone means to discuss something with them to make a decision.
exam: I will have to confer with my wife before I can purchase a new car.

desc: When things are consecutive, they happen one after another without interruption.
exam: The king ruled for ten consecutive years.

desc: When something is crude, it is not exact or detailed, but it can still be useful.
exam: She drew crude hearts on the ground to show how much she loved him.

desc: A cube is a solid object with six square surfaces that are all the same size.
exam: Please get me some ice cubes to put in my soda.

desc: Feedback is comments to a person about how they are doing something.
exam: I asked my boss for feedback on my work.

desc: Ignorance of something is lack of knowledge about it.
exam: When he failed the test, his ignorance of math was obvious.

desc: When something is masculine, it is a quality or thing related to men.
exam: American football is usually considered a masculine sport.

desc: A monument is a structure that is built to remind people of a person or event.
exam: A large monument was built to honor the brave soldiers.

desc: When someone is muscular, they are very fit and strong.
exam: He exercised regularly so that his body could become muscular.

desc: A person’s posture is the position in which they stand or sit.
exam: Your back will feel better if you improve your posture.

desc: To situate something means to place or build it in a certain place.
exam: The road was situated between the forest and the lake.

desc: To supervise something means to make sure that it is done correctly.
exam: Allen supervised the construction workers to ensure everyone’s safety.

desc: Symmetry is the state of having two halves that are exactly the same.
exam: The artist made sure to use perfect symmetry when painting the butterfly.

desc: A tattoo is a design that is drawn permanently on the skin with needles.
exam: The surfer had tattoos on both his arms.

desc: An undergraduate is a student at a college who is studying fora bachelor’s degree.
exam: She was excited to finish high school and enroll as an undergraduate in the fall.

desc: A brook is a small stream.
exam: Water flows down several brooks on the mountain.

desc: To cater to someone means to provide them with all the things needed or wanted.
exam: Bill was too sick to get out of bed, so his nurse catered to his needs.

desc: When someone is considerate, they pay attention to the needs of others.
exam: The considerate boy gave a present to his girlfriend on Valentine’s Day.

desc: The consumption of food or drink is the act of eating or drinking it.
exam: These apples are too rotten for consumption.

desc: Criteria are factors on which a person judges or decides something.
exam: Before she got the job, she had to meet all the necessary criteria.

desc: Crust is the tough outer part of a loaf of bread.
exam: The little boy never ate the crust of his pizza.

desc: To degrade someone means to cause people to have shame.
exam: The teacher degraded Bob when she announced his poor performance to the class

desc: To entitle someone means to give them the rights to have or do something.
exam: His golden ticket entitled him to sit in the front row at the concert.

desc: To escort people means to safely accompany them to a place.
exam: Her bodyguards escorted her to the movie theater.

desc: When something is external, it is connected to an outer part.
exam: It is warm inside my house, but the external temperature is freezing.

desc: A facility is a building that exists for a particular purpose.
exam: There are many educational facilities in big cities.

desc: A faculty is a mental or physical ability.
exam: The boy’s mental faculties impressed all of his teachers.

desc: A heap of things is a large pile of them.
exam: After the building was torn down, all that was left was a heap of bricks.

desc: A hemisphere is one half of the earth.
exam: In the northern hemisphere, the weather is usually warmest in July and August.

desc: A hound is a type of dog that is often used for racing or hunting.
exam: The men took their hounds with them when they went on the hunting trip.

desc: If something is impersonal, it is not friendly and makes people feel unimportant.
exam: The boy felt scared on his first day at the big, impersonal high school.

desc: An ornament is an attractive object that people display in their homes.
exam: The woman kept some colorful ornaments on the shelves.

desc: A pedestrian is a person who is walking on a street.
exam: Cars should be careful when pedestrians are walking around.

desc: A sanctuary is a place where people in danger can go to be safe.
exam: The church was made into a sanctuary for homeless people in the winter.

desc: A spectator is someone who watches something, especially a sports event.
exam: There were thousands of spectators at the big game.

desc: An asset is a skill or quality that is useful or valuable.
exam: The coach realized the boy’s speed was an asset to the team.

desc: An aspect is one part or feature of something.
exam: I thought about the different aspects of owning two dogs.

desc: Braille is a system of raised patterns on paper that allows the blind to read.
exam: The boy enjoyed reading his favorite books written in Braille.

desc: A bud is a part of a plant that turns into a flower or a leaf.
exam: Two weeks after planting the seed, a small bud appeared.

desc: To coordinate things is to make different parts work together.
exam: Each skating team had to coordinate their movements for the show.

desc: To disprove something means to show that it is not true.
exam: The scientist disproved the theory that the sun moved around the Earth.

desc: If something is humanitarian, it is connected to helping people’s lives.
exam: After the flood, several humanitarian organizations offered help.

desc: A hypothesis is an idea for something that has not been proved yet.
exam: The teacher did an experiment to prove whether his hypothesis was right.

desc: An imprint is an effect or lesson from an experience that is hard to forget.
exam: The experience ofwarleftan imprint on his mind that troubled him.

desc: When something is informative, it provides a lot of information.
exam: The travel guide had a lot of informative facts about the region.

desc: When something is optic, it relates to the eyes or light.
exam: Her blindness was caused by a problem with her optic nerve.

desc: A premise is an idea on which something is based.
exam: The premise of the movie that Bobbi and I watched was unrealistic.

desc: A rack is an object with shelves that holds things.
exam: He stored his tools on a rack.

desc: The Renaissance was a period between the 14th and 17th centuries.
exam: Leonardo Da Vinci was a popular artist of the Renaissance.

desc: To revere something is to admire it greatly.
exam: The students revere their teacher, who has taught them a lot.

desc: When something is simultaneous, it occurs at the same time as something else.
exam: The movement of the gears inside the watch was simultaneous.

desc: A skeptic is a person who does not believe something.
exam: The scientist showed the skeptic that dinosaurs did exist by providing evidence.

desc: When something is spatial, it relates to the position and size of things.
exam: He was asked where the books were located to test his spatial ability.

desc: To specify is to describe something clearly.
exam: The poster didn’t specify where the concert was taking place.

desc: Wax is a substance that is slightly shiny and melts when heated.
exam: The candles are made of wax.

desc: An accessory is a thing that is added to another thing to make it look better.
exam: The store sold colorful accessories like bags, sunglasses, and makeup.

desc: An acquisition is something that a person buys or gets in some way.
exam: Marty was happy with his new acquisition: a very fast bicycle.

desc: When something is adequate, it is good enough for something else.
exam: Without adequate notice of the road block, they will have to turn around.

desc: Cardboard is a material made out of stiff paper. It is often used to make boxes.
exam: We packed our things into cardboard boxes and moved to our new home.

desc: A dilemma is a difficult situation in which a choice has to be made.
exam: Choosing either the tastier or healthier drink proved to be quite a dilemma.

desc: When something is elaborate, it contains a lot of details.
exam: She gave the teacher an elaborate explanation of her project.

desc: To facilitate something is to make it easier.
exam: To facilitate the meeting, Melissa used a simple computer program.

desc: A fleet is a group of ships.
exam: The fleet of ships spent a few days at the dock.

desc: A grid is a pattern of squares with numbers and letters to find places on a map.
exam: We located our town using the grid.

desc: To import means to bring in a product from another country.
exam: Foods that have been imported are usually more expensive.

desc: To infer something is to decide it is true based on other information one has.
exam: By the position of the sun in the sky, she inferred that it was noon.

desc: To inflate something means to fill it up with air.
exam: I helped him inflate the balloons.

desc: When something is innate, it is something that one is born with, it is not learned.
exam: He had the innate desire to please his teachers.

desc: Marble is a type of rock that feels cold and is smooth when cut.
exam: The large house had floors made of marble.

desc: A mast is a long pole on a ship that holds the sail.
exam: The mast held both sails of the ship upright.

desc: Nausea is the feeling of being sick to your stomach.
exam: The doctor said the medicine would help get rid of her nausea.

desc: When something is naval, it relates to a country’s navy or military ships.
exam: The country sent all of its naval forces to protect them.

desc: A pouch is a small, flexible bag that is usually made of cloth.
exam: I keep my money in a small pouch.

desc: If something is saturated, it is completely wet.
exam: Leigh’s hair became saturated in the rain storm.

desc: An update is an act of making something more modern.
exam: I’m doing an update on my personal phone directory.

desc: An addict is a person who cannot stop doing or having something.
exam: She was a coffee addict. She had more than three cups each day.

desc: When something is archeological, it relates to archeology.
exam: They found archeological evidence that proved an ancient species of man.

desc: Archeology is the study of ancient people through their artifacts.
exam: He studied archeology to learn more about ancient Egyptian culture.

desc: To brainstorm is to have a lot of ideas about a certain topic.
exam: The students met after school to brainstorm ideas for their assignment.

desc: A budget is the amount of money available to spend on something.
exam: His budget for food was very tight.

desc: When something is chaotic, it is crazy, confused, and hectic.
exam: The first day of school can be chaotic for a new student.

desc: To cite something is to mention it as an example or as proof of something.
exam: She cited six reasons that the school needed to build new classrooms.

desc: To correspond is to match or to be similar to something.
exam: The boy’s story didn’t correspond with his mother’s version.

desc: A courtyard is an outdoor area that is surrounded by the walls of a building.
exam: During the summer, the courtyard is a nice place to have lunch.

desc: An estate is a large area of land owned by a family or organization.
exam: He lived on his father’s estate in the country.

desc: Fraud is the crime of gaining money by lying or by tricking people.
exam: Experts say that credit card fraud increases around the holidays.

desc: Hydrogen is a gas that has no taste, color, or smell.
exam: Balloons filled with hydrogen can easily float away if you aren’t careful.

desc: Integrity is honesty and good morals.
exam: The principal had a lot of integrity.

desc: To knit is to make fabric by connecting strings together.
exam: My grandmother knitted me a sweater.

desc: An outlook is a person’s opinion or way of thinking about something.
exam: He changed his outlook about rats after he read a book about them.

desc: A parachute is a device that helps people and things fall to the ground safely.
exam: They used parachutes dropped from airplanes to send supplies to the civilians.

desc: When something is prehistoric, it is from a time when there was no written history.
exam: The scientists found prehistoric pots used by the people in the area.

desc: A proponent is a person who supports an idea or a plan.
exam: He was a proponent of using environmentally friendly products.

desc: To refine something is to make it better by making changes.
exam: The principal refined his method of controlling students over the years.

desc: To restrict is to limit something and prevent it from getting bigger.
exam: The club restricted the amount of members.

desc: An attorney is one who gives others advice about the law.
exam: The attorney appeared in front of the judge for me.

desc: When something is chronic, it happens over and over again over time.
exam: He had chronic pain in his chest and needed to see a doctor.

desc: Discipline is training that helps people follow the rules.
exam: One of the teacher’s jobs is to teach her students discipline.

desc: A donor is somebody who gives something to an organization.
exam: He was proud to be a blood donor.

desc: A fellow is someone who shares a job or quality with someone else.
exam: All of my fellow patients at the hospital have also complained about the food.

desc: Gossip is information that might be untrue but is still discussed anyway.
exam: The friends exchanged gossip about the people they knew in school.

desc: To graduate from a school means to complete and pass all courses of study there.
exam: At the end of the spring, my friends and I will graduate from high school.

desc: Graffiti is words or drawings in public places.
exam: The wall was covered with colorful graffiti.

desc: A guardian is someone who protects somebody or something.
exam: The librarians are the guardians of the books.

desc: To implicate someone is to show that they have done a crime or something bad.
exam: The man was implicated in the theft at the store.

desc: Kin is a person’s family and relatives.
exam: His kin were all farmers.

desc: A referee is a person who makes sure that the rules are followed in sports.
exam: The soccer player didn’t agree with the referee.

desc: To sever something is to cut through it completely.
exam: He severed the string using scissors.

desc: A shaft is a handle of a tool or weapon.
exam: The golf club had a long wooden shaft that he held in his hands.

desc: To stab means to cut someone or something with a sharp object like a knife.
exam: He stabbed the fork into the potato and passed it to his daughter.

desc: A stimulus is something that causes growth or activity.
exam: Having a lot of money is a stimulus for people to buy more things.

desc: A suspicion is a feeling that something is possible or true in a crime.
exam: The police had a suspicion that the driver had stolen the purse.

desc: To terminate something means to stop or end it.
exam: The trip was terminated after the car broke down.

desc: A theme is the main subject of a book, movie, or painting.
exam: The students discussed the book’s theme in class.

desc: Tuition is the amount of money paid to go to a school.
exam: University tuitions have increased by fifty percent in the last five years.

desc: If someone is aggressive, then they constantly want to fight.
exam: Nobody liked to play games with him because he was always too aggressive.

desc: Amnesty is a pardon given to prisoners of war.
exam: She was denied amnesty for her involvement in the war.

desc: An arena is a building where people can watch sports and concerts.
exam: The new arena was all set to hold the championship match.

desc: An auditorium is a large building used for public events.
exam: People have gathered at the school auditorium to watch the play.

desc: A captive is a prisoner.
exam: The guards told the captive that there was no way he could escape the prison.

desc: Combat is fighting between two people or groups.
exam: The two warriors were locked in combat.

desc: If something is commonplace, then it is ordinary.
exam: There is nothing commonplace about the way Morris dresses.

desc: A compound is an enclosed area such as a prison or factory.
exam: The workers waited outside the compound for the gates to the factory to open.

desc: A corps is a division of a military force.
exam: The army had a corps of archers who trained apart from the regular soldiers.

desc: To distract someone means to stop them from concentrating on something.
exam: The phone call distracted him so much that he forgot all about his homework.

desc: If someone is dumb, they are unable to speak.
exam: She did not share the secret. She remained silent as if she were dumb.

desc: A foe is an enemy or opponent.
exam: It was hard to believe that anyone could be his foe.

desc: To hack something means to cut it into uneven pieces.
exam: My uncle used the ax to hack the tree into many logs.

desc: To meditate means to focus or think deeply in silence.
exam: She liked to meditate for several hours of each day.

desc: To nick someone means to cut them slightly with a sharp object.
exam: While cutting the carrots, the cook nicked his finger with the edge of his knife.

desc: To provoke someone means to annoy them on purpose to cause violence.
exam: The older boy provoked Paul by calling him mean names.

desc: A realm is any area of activity or interest.
exam: He was not very active in the realm of business.

desc: A reign is the period of time in which a ruler rules.
exam: The emperor’s reign lasted for only two years.

desc: Rust is a red and brown coating on iron objects caused by water and air.
exam: The old metal gate would not swing because the hinges were covered in rust.

desc: If something is sacred, then it is worshipped and respected.
exam: One religion in India will not harm cows because it believes that they are sacred.

desc: If someone acts accordingly, they act in a way that is suitable.
exam: He feels like he did a good job, and his boss should pay him accordingly.

desc: An anchor is a heavy object dropped from a boat to make it stay in one place.
exam: When the ship reached its destination, the crew dropped the anchor.

desc: A buoy is a floating sign that warns boats of dangerous areas.
exam: Don’t steer the boat near those buoys. There are rocks underneath the water.

desc: A catastrophe is an unexpected event that causes great suffering or damage.
exam: It was a catastrophe for my family when my dad lost his job.

desc: Context is the situations that form the background of an event.
exam: They studied the context of the battle before giving their presentation.

desc: To designate someone or something means to give them a particular description.
exam: The famous lighthouse was designated a historical monument.

desc: To distort something means to lie about it.
exam: His lawyer distorted the facts so that he would be set free.

desc: A dock is an enclosed area where ships go to be loaded, unloaded, and repaired.
exam: The huge ship pulled into the dock, and the crew unloaded the cargo.

desc: The fore of something is the front part of it.
exam: The teacher’s desk is at the fore of the classroom.

desc: If something is frequent, then it happens or is done often.
exam: While Dad was sick, the doctor made frequent visits to his house.

desc: When something is genuine, it is true or real.
exam: After the painting was determined to be genuine, it sold for a million dollars.

desc: Grease is an oily substance put on moving parts, so they work smoothly.
exam: When I was done working on the car, I had grease all over my hands.

desc: When something is intricate, it has many small parts or details.
exam: The intricate painting on the quilt was very lovely.

desc: To offset means to use one thing to cancel out the effect of another thing.
exam: Increased wages are offset by higher prices for goods.

desc: To overlap something means to cover a piece of it.
exam: The gift on top overlaps the other gift on the bottom.

desc: To precipitate an event means to cause it to happen sooner than normal.
exam: The violent attack precipitated an all-out war.

desc: When something is secondhand, it has been owned by someone else.
exam: Her secondhand jeans were a bit faded in the front.

desc: A slot is a narrow opening in a machine or container.
exam: To operate the machine, put your coins into the slot.

desc: To submerge something means to put it below the surface of a liquid.
exam: The whale submerged its huge body into the ocean.

desc: A tactic is a careful plan to achieve something.
exam: Sam thought of a good tactic in order to attract more business.

desc: When a number is aggregate, it is made up of smaller amounts added together.
exam: The company totaled its aggregate sales for the entire year.

desc: An antibiotic is a medical drug used to kill bacteria and treat infections.
exam: The doctor gave me a shot of an antibiotic when I got the flu.

desc: A circuit is a piece of an electronic device that allows electricity to flow.
exam: Be very careful not to shock yourself when fixing an electrical circuit.

desc: To complement something or someone is to make them better.
exam: The wool scarf complemented her lovely eyes.

desc: To compress something means to press or squeeze it so that it takes up less space.
exam: I compressed my clothes to fit into a single suitcase.

desc: A database is a collection of data that is stored in a computer.
exam: The company has a database of all the names and accounts of their customers.

desc: An equivalent is an amount or value that is the same as another amount or value.
exam: I worked the equivalent of sixty hours this week.

desc: When someone is immune to a disease, they cannot be affected by it.
exam: Children usually get shots to make them immune to certain diseases.

desc: Input is information that is put into a computer.
exam: Type the input into the computer program.

desc: When a relationship is intimate, the two things are very closely connected.
exam: I only tell my secrets to my most intimate friends.

desc: A magnet is a piece of iron or other material which attracts iron toward it.
exam: I used a magnet to pick up the nails that were scattered on the floor.

desc: A person’s metabolism is the way chemical processes in their body use energy.
exam: If you exercise every day, your metabolism speeds up.

desc: A microchip is a small device inside a computer that holds information.
exam: I can put more data on my computer if I buy a more powerful microchip.

desc: A phase is a stage in a process or the gradual development of something.
exam: The first phase in the recycling project involves finding volunteers to help out.

desc: To pinch means to take a piece of skin between one’s fingers and squeeze.
exam: I pinched my nose, so I couldn’t smell the odor from the garbage.

desc: When something is prevalent, it is common.
exam: Growing a beard is more prevalent behavior in men than women.

desc: When something is quantum, it relates to the behavior of atomic particles.
exam: The physics student studied quantum mechanics.

desc: A ratio is a relationship between two things expressed in numbers or amounts.
exam: The boy to girl ratio is one to three.

desc: A spiral is a shape which winds round and round in a larger and larger circle.
exam: A strand of DNA looks like two interlocking spirals.

desc: When something is viral, it is a disease or infection that is caused by a virus.
exam: The girl was in bed fora week when she had a viral infection.

desc: If you are astounded, you are very surprised.
exam: I was astounded that Monica won the art competition.

desc: An attribute is a characteristic of a person or thing.
exam: He isn’t very clever, but he does have some other positive attributes.

desc: If someone is bilingual, then they can speak two languages.
exam: Since you already know English, after learning French you’ll be bilingual.

desc: A clone is an identical copy of a living creature.
exam: Scientists recently made a clone of a sheep.

desc: Colloquial describes informal words that are more suitable for speech than writing.
exam: I find it difficult to understand people if they use colloquial language.

desc: Cosmetics are substances that make the face and skin more beautiful.
exam: Girls often look nicer when they don’t use so many cosmetics.

desc: To dash means to run or move quickly.
exam: Helen dashed up the stairs, so she wouldn’t be late for her appointment.

desc: Disgust is a feeling of distaste and anger caused by something rude or unpleasant.
exam: He felt disgust toward his date because she had such terrible eating habits.

desc: If something is fluorescent, it is such a bright color that it seems to give off light.
exam: She highlighted the key words in the document with a fluorescent yellow pen.

desc: If you are furious, you are extremely angry.
exam: My father was furious when he read my bad school report.

desc: A gulf is a gap between people who do not understand each other.
exam: There has been a gulf between James and Tony since their parents died.

desc: Humanities are subjects which analyze human ideas, such as history and literature.
exam: Jennifer has always been more interested in humanities than science.

desc: A knot is made when you tie the ends of rope or cord together.
exam: He tied a knot in his shoelaces, so they wouldn’t come off during the race.

desc: A linguist is someone who studies languages.
exam: Tony is a good linguist and speaks four different languages.

desc: A participant is someone who joins in a social event or competition.
exam: There were thousands of participants in this year’s marathon.

desc: If something is plausible, it is reasonable or possible.
exam: It is plausible that Jack isn’t here today because he is sick.

desc: A ritual is a formal custom that people do regularly.
exam: Ken was very interested to learn about the religious rituals of the natives.

desc: A sibling is a brother or sister.
exam: Jane has two siblings, an older brother and a younger sister.

desc: If someone is skinny, they are extremely thin.
exam: Polly is very skinny. I think she needs to eat more.

desc: If something is vague, it is not clear, and it gives very few details.
exam: I asked him about his mother’s health, but he was very vague about it.

desc: An acid is a chemical that can burn or dissolve other substances.
exam: In chemistry class, we mixed two acids together and watched the reaction.

desc: An administration is the group of people who manage a company or organization.
exam: She hoped she could be promoted to a job in the administration.

desc: Administrative describes anything related to managing a company or organization.
exam: I work as an administrative assistant to the owner of the company.

desc: Biotechnology is the use of living parts, such as cells, in industry and technology.
exam: Researchers at the biotechnology company use bacteria to make medicine.

desc: Cholesterol is a substance in fat, tissues, and blood of all animals.
exam: When people have too much cholesterol, they are at a high risk for heart problems.

desc: A coalition is a group of people or organizations working for a common purpose.
exam: The companies formed a coalition to make trade less expensive.

desc: When something is deceptive, it encourages one to believe something that is false.
exam: The scary-looking man’s appearance is deceptive, but he is actually very nice.

desc: Diabetes is a medical condition where a person has too much sugar in their blood.
exam: Overweight people are more likely to suffer from diabetes than slimmer ones.

desc: To eliminate something that is unwanted means to completely remove it.
exam: Wearing a seatbelt eliminates some of the dangers of driving a car.

desc: Erosion is the destruction of rock or soil due to flowing water or weather.
exam: Canyons are formed because rivers of fast-moving water caused erosion.

desc: Ethics are moral beliefs or rules about right or wrong.
exam: The act of stealing certainly doesn’t go against some people’s ethics.

desc: If something is explicit, it is very clear, open, and truthful.
exam: The man gave a very explicit account of the car accident.

desc: A framework is a set of rules or ideas that people use to solve problems.
exam: His ideas fit into the framework of a successful business plan.

desc: To manufacture something means to make it in a factory.
exam: My father’s company manufactures steel building materials.

desc: A mechanism is a part of a machine that performs a certain function.
exam: I can’t open my car door because the locking mechanism is broke.

desc: To minimize means to reduce something to the lowest possible level.
exam: I checked my homework twice to minimize errors I might have made.

desc: Nectar is a sweet liquid produced by flowers that bees and other insects collect.
exam: Bees use nectar to make their honey.

desc: A notion is an idea or belief about something.
exam: I have a notion that this route would get us to the beach.

desc: When things are prone to some bad thing, they are likely affected by it.
exam: Some people are more prone to catching colds than others.

desc: When something is straightforward, it is good because it is easy to understand.
exam: The teacher’s grading system was straightforward and fair.

desc: If something is astronomical, then it is extremely large.
exam: It’s an astronomical distance between the Milky Way galaxy and the nearest galaxy.

desc: An atom is the smallest unit of a substance.
exam: A molecule consists of a combination of two or more atoms.

desc: Breadth is the distance from one side to the other side of something.
exam: The breadth of the northern wall of the house is twenty meters.

desc: A circumference is the distance completely around a circular object.
exam: The circumference of the Earth is obviously much larger than a baseball’s.

desc: A comet is an object in space made of ice and rock with a tail of glowing dust.
exam: Comets take many decades to complete an orbit around a star.

desc: A crater is a large hole in a planet’s or moon’s surface.
exam: They could clearly see the big crater on the moon through the telescope.

desc: A crescent is the curved shape lit on the moon’s face during its early and late stages.
exam: Ten days ago the entire moon was bright, but now only a small crescent is shining.

desc: Debris is the small pieces scattered from something wrecked or destroyed.
exam: The debris from the cube scattered on the floor.

desc: Despair is the complete loss of hope.
exam: After the other company won the account, our salespeople were filled with despair.

desc: To embed something means to place it firmly within a surrounding thing.
exam: The logger embedded the ax into the wood after chopping several logs.

desc: A fragment is a small part of something.
exam: After the light broke, there were fragments of glass to clean up.

desc: A galaxy is any extremely large collection of star systems.
exam: Our solar system is located in the outer area of our galaxy.

desc: If something is gigantic, then it is extremely large.
exam: Some dinosaurs were so gigantic that they were the size of buildings.

desc: Gloom is a state of being almost completely dark.
exam: In the gloom of the morning, it was difficult to see the boat on the lake.

desc: To radiate means to send out energy or heat.
exam: The heat from the fireplace radiated throughout the room.

desc: To roam means to move around without a plan or purpose.
exam: All day the cows roamed around the field eating grass.

desc: If something is solitary, then it is lonely or the only one.
exam: The only thing in the room was a solitary chair.

desc: The spectrum is the full range of color ranging from red to violet.
exam: You can see the entire spectrum in a rainbow.

desc: A sphere is a three-dimensional round shape, like a ball.
exam: The balloons were inflated into a variety of colorful spheres.

desc: Status is the position of something or someone in relation to others.
exam: She had achieved the status of being the smartest girl in the class.

desc: If someone is bankrupt, then they are unable to pay their debts.
exam: The store had few customers and soon went bankrupt.

desc: To conform to rules or laws is to obey them.
exam: The new student had to conform to the school’s dress code.

desc: To employ someone means to give work to them.
exam: The bookstore employed two full-time clerks.

desc: To expel someone means to force them to leave a place.
exam: Since he would not follow the rules, the principal had to expel the student.

desc: An extension is a part added to something to give it more time or space.
exam: My parents decided to add an extension to our house for the new baby.

desc: If something is forthcoming, then it is about to happen in the future.
exam: Some economists predicted that the forthcoming world economy would be severe.

desc: To furnish means to put furniture in a house or room.
exam: Most homes are furnished with tables, chairs, and beds.

desc: Hygiene is the conditions or methods needed for health and cleanliness.
exam: People who brush their teeth at least twice a day are practicing good hygiene.

desc: If something is hygienic, then it is clean and unlikely to cause disease.
exam: My sister works very hard to keep her entire home as hygienic as possible.

desc: A landlord is a man who rents property to a person.
exam: The landlord collected everyone’s rent money on the first day of every month.

desc: To lease means to rent property, usually an apartment or land.
exam: When the family first leased the apartment, the rent was very low.

desc: If something is mandatory, then it is required by law.
exam: It’s mandatory that everyone be at least sixteen to drive a car in the US.

desc: To mend something means to fix it when it is broken or damaged.
exam: Mother mended the rip in my pants with a piece of cloth.

desc: A mortgage is a loan for property, especially homes and businesses.
exam: When they bought their new home, the married couple had to sign a mortgage.

desc: Personnel are employees in a business.
exam: When business increased, we had to hire more personnel.

desc: Plumbing is the system of pipes used in a home to supply water.
exam: When the plumbing stopped working, no one was allowed to use the toilets.

desc: A tenant is a person who rents property from a landlord.
exam: The new tenants moved into the house across the street.

desc: If something is trendy, then it is very popular and new.
exam: Carlo bought a trendy new car.

desc: A utility is a business that supplies services such as water or electricity.
exam: If you don’t pay the utilities, you may have your electricity turned off.

desc: Whereby means by which or through which.
exam: The mayor had a new bridge built whereby the citizens could cross the river.

desc: If something is aesthetic, then it is concerned with a love of beauty.
exam: The dresses were noteworthy for their aesthetic design.

desc: If someone is arrogant, they think that they are more important than others.
exam: He is very arrogant. Even though he’s not the boss, he tells everyone what to do.

desc: A bias is a person’s likelihood to like one thing more than another thing.
exam: The mothers had a natural bias for their own child’s picture.

desc: A canyon is a narrow valley with steep walls through which a river often flows.
exam: The canyon was so deep that the ground inside was covered in shadow.

desc: A creek is a stream or small river.
exam: Only small fish lived in the shallow waters of the creek.

desc: A drill is a tool with a point that spins in order to make a hole.
exam: The carpenter used the drill to make several holes in the wood.

desc: An executive is the top manager of a business.
exam: After twenty years at the company, he finally became the executive.

desc: Fatigue is a feeling of extreme tiredness.
exam: After three days with little sleep, she was feeling a lot of fatigue.

desc: An incline is a sharp rise in something, especially a hill or mountain.
exam: This mountain has one of the steepest inclines in the world.

desc: If something is nasty, then it is not nice or pleasant.
exam: The rotten apple left a nasty taste inside her mouth.

desc: To perceive something means to be aware of it.
exam: He was talking loudly, so he did not perceive that the music had stopped.

desc: A primate is a type of mammal that includes monkeys, apes, and humans.
exam: Primates use their hands for such tasks as swinging from branches.

desc: If something is primitive, then it is simple, basic, and not very developed.
exam: The computers of the 1980s are primitive compared to those of todays.

desc: A stereotype is a general but often incorrect idea about a person or thing.
exam: There’s a stereotype that pigs are dirty animals. But they are rather clean.

desc: If something is sticky, then it is covered with a substance that things stick to.
exam: Place the sticky part of the tape against the paper, so it will cling to the wall.

desc: A termite is an insect that lives in groups and feeds on wood.
exam: The wood we found was full of termites.

desc: If something happens thereby an action, then it is the result of that action.
exam: He didn’t score a goal, thereby ending his chance at setting a record.

desc: A trail is a path through a wild area.
exam: A narrow trail cut through the field and over the hills.

desc: A twig is a short and thin branch from a tree or bush.
exam: They started the fire with a handful of dry twigs.

desc: Welfare is the health and happiness of a person or group.
exam: Having plenty of clean water is necessary for the welfare of people.

desc: If something is done on one’s behalf, it is done for that person by another.
exam: The original speaker was sick, so his son gave the speech on his behalf.

desc: To flap means to move quickly up and down or from side to side.
exam: The tiny bird flapped its wings and ate from the flowers.

desc: A glacier is a large piece of ice that moves very slowly.
exam: The North Pole is covered by a huge glacier.

desc: The globe refers to the Earth.
exam: Water covers most of the globe.

desc: When something is horizontal, it is flat and level with the ground.
exam: The Russian flag has three horizontal stripes of white, blue, and red.

desc: To hum means to make a low, continuous noise.
exam: The man hummed his favorite song.

desc: An inventory is a supply of something.
exam: Gwen was checking the inventory to make sure we had what we needed.

desc: If a thought or feeling is inward, it is not expressed or shown to others.
exam: She had an inward feeling of guilt when she lied to her mother.

desc: A loaf of bread is bread shaped and baked in one piece.
exam: Could you please buy a loaf of bread for sandwiches?

desc: An oracle is person who speaks with gods and gives advice about the future.
exam: The king went to the oracle to ask if going to war was a good idea.

desc: To orbit something means to move around it in a continuous, curving path.
exam: The moon orbits the Earth.

desc: An overview is a general description of a situation.
exam: My brother gave me an overview of the important parts of the book.

desc: A preview is an opportunity to see something before it is available to the public.
exam: The band played us a preview of their new song.

desc: If something is previous, then it happened earlier in time or order.
exam: He turned back to the previous page to read the paragraph again.

desc: To provide something means to supply it.
exam: Each student was provided with a test and three sharp pencils.

desc: To recur means to happen more than once.
exam: Burglaries seem to recur over and over in our neighborhood.

desc: When something is relevant, it is important to a certain person or situation.
exam: The thirty-year-old book about politics is still relevant to our society today.

desc: A rite is a traditional ceremony carried out by a particular group or society.
exam: Special masks are worn during the rite when a new baby is born.

desc: To stall means to stop a process and continue it at a later time.
exam: If you give the car a push, it won’t stall.

desc: If something is supernatural, it is not real or explainable by natural law.
exam: The dragon had supernatural powers such as flying and breathing fire.

desc: To adapt means to change in order to deal with a new situation or addition.
exam: When he went to the new town, he had to adapt to all the weather changes.

desc: Biological describes the process of life and living things.
exam: In science, we learned about the biological process of bacterial growth.

desc: When something is cellular, it relates to the cells of animals or plants.
exam: She used a microscope to see the activity at a cellular level.

desc: When people are dynamic, they are lively and have creative ideas.
exam: The new, dynamic employee came up with a good way to juggle his work load.

desc: A fantasy is a pleasant situation that people think about but is unlikely to happen.
exam: Becoming an astronaut is a fantasy shared by many children.

desc: Heredity is the process of passing on features from parents to children.
exam: The boy’s face is similar to his father’s because of heredity.

desc: When something is internal, it exists or happens inside a person, object, or place.
exam: We removed the outer case to reveal the computer’s internal wires.

desc: When something is minimal, it is very small.
exam: My lazy husband does a minimal amount of work around the house.

desc: A pioneer is a person who is the first to discover or be involved in something.
exam: He was a pioneer of computer programming.

desc: To prescribe medicine means to tell someone to take it.
exam: When I was sick, the doctor prescribed me flu medicine.

desc: When things are respective, they relate separately to each person just mentioned.
exam: The boxers were told to return to their respective corners.

desc: To revive someone or something means to restore health or life to them.
exam: She revived the feeling of warmth in her leg by rubbing it softly.

desc: When rules or systems are rigid, they are severe because they cannot be changed.
exam: Societies often have rigid rules about the way that people are supposed to act.

desc: A sequence is a number of events or things that come one after another.
exam: The dominos fell in a sequence of one after another.

desc: To substitute something or someone means to have them take the place of another.
exam: When I ran out of juice, I had to substitute water to drink in the morning.

desc: A surgeon is a doctor who is trained to do surgery.
exam: The surgeon operated on the old man’s heart.

desc: Therapy is treatment for a particular physical or mental illness or condition.
exam: After she broke her legs, she used physical therapy to learn how to walk again.

desc: To transfer something means to move it from one place to another.
exam: The family transferred the groceries from the shopping cart to the car.

desc: A transition is a process where there is a change from one form to another.
exam: The weather gets colder during the transition from summer to autumn.

desc: A transplant is an operation in which a damaged part of one’s body is replaced.
exam: The sick child needed a heart transplant to live.

desc: An aquarium is a building where fish and underwater animals are kept.
exam: We took a trip to the aquarium and saw a scary shark.

desc: If something is arbitrary, it is not based on any plan or system, so it seems random.
exam: The classroom had many arbitrary rules that made me confused.

desc: An autobiography is a true story of a person’s life written by that person.
exam: I read an autobiography about my favorite entertainer.

desc: A convention is behavior that is considered to be common or polite.
exam: In the US, a popular convention is to shake hands when you meet someone.

desc: If someone is gracious, then they are kind and helpful to those who need it.
exam: The operator was gracious enough to help me find his number.

desc: To improve something means to make it better.
exam: He studied hard to improve his test scores from the previous year.

desc: To insulate something means to protect it from heat, cold, or noise.
exam: People can conserve energy by insulating their houses.

desc: To intrigue means to cause an interest in something or someone.
exam: Her mysterious past intrigued her new friend.

desc: Longevity is the ability to live for a long time.
exam: Sea turtles have an amazing longevity.

desc: To misplace something means to lose it.
exam: I misplaced my wallet, and I didn’t find it until a week later.

desc: When children are naughty, they behave badly or do not do what they are told.
exam: The boy had to go to his room because he was being naughty.

desc: A norm is a way of behaving that is considered normal in a particular society.
exam: Wearing a heavy coat all summer is not considered a norm in the desert.

desc: An orangutan is a large ape with red and brown hair and long arms.
exam: Orangutans use their long arms to swing from trees.

desc: To overload something means to put more things into it than it is meant to hold.
exam: If you overload the truck, it might crash.

desc: Philanthropy is the act of helping others, without wanting anything in return.
exam: The wealthy business owner is well known for his acts of philanthropy.

desc: To probe into something means to ask questions to discover facts about it.
exam: The bank probed into his financial history to see if he qualified for a loan.

desc: A recipient of something is the person who receives it.
exam: I was the recipient of four phone calls today.

desc: A reptile is a cold-blooded animal that lays eggs and has skin covered with scales.
exam: Lizards are my favorite type of reptile.

desc: To thrive means to do well and be successful, healthy, or strong.
exam: He may be an old man, but he continues to thrive.

desc: When something is ultimate, it is the final result or aim of a long series of events.
exam: By trying hard in school, I will reach my ultimate goal of becoming a doctor.

desc: If something is antique, it is very old and rare, and therefore valuable.
exam: My grandmother’s antique rocking chair is worth a lot of money.

desc: An applicant is someone who writes a request to be considered for a job or prize.
exam: Lots of applicants came into the store when the job position became available.

desc: An artifact is an old object made by humans that is historically interesting.
exam: We studied artifacts from an ancient Chinese settlement.

desc: When something is authentic, it is not false or a copy of the original.
exam: We ate authentic Italian food on our vacation to Rome.

desc: The chronology of a series of past events is when they happened.
exam: We learned the chronology of World War II in history class.

desc: A diplomat is a representative of a country who works with another country.
exam: The Spanish diplomat discussed trade issues with officials in Peru.

desc: An epic is a long book, poem, or movie about a period of time or a great event.
exam: The poet wrote an epic about the great discoveries of the past thousand years.

desc: An excerpt is a short piece of writing or music taken from a larger piece.
exam: I didn’t listen to the entire symphony online, but I did play an excerpt.

desc: A fossil is the hard remains of a prehistoric animal or plant.
exam: The expert arranged the fossils to build the skeleton of the dinosaur.

desc: To humiliate someone means to make them feel ashamed and embarrassed.
exam: I was humiliated when I tripped and fell down in front of the whole school.

desc: When a poem is considered lyric, it is written in a simple and direct style.
exam: I enjoy reading and creating my own lyric poetry.

desc: Majesty is supreme greatness or authority.
exam: You should address the king and queen as your majesty.

desc: The monarch of a country is the king, queen, emperor, or empress.
exam: The monarch lived in a beautiful palace with a grand gate.

desc: To precede something means to come before it.
exam: The hurricane was preceded by a moment of still wind and clear sky.

desc: When someone is punctual, they do something or arrive at the right time.
exam: My mother hates being late. She is the most punctual person I know.

desc: To recruit people means to select them to join or work for an organization.
exam: We successfully recruited someone to be the new manager.

desc: A refund is money given back to a person when an item is returned to a store.
exam: I asked for a refund because the shoes I bought were too tight.

desc: A register is an official list or record of people or things.
exam: At a wedding there is register for all of the guests to sign.

desc: Renown is the quality of being well known due to having done good things.
exam: Michael is a singer of great renown in New Zealand.

desc: A tusk is a long, curved, pointed tooth of an elephant, boar, or walrus.
exam: Sadly, some people hunt elephants and remove their tusks to sell them.

desc: A burden is a serious or difficult responsibility.
exam: Children who do not behave are a burden to their parents.

desc: To compromise is to agree to something that is not exactly what you want.
exam: We both compromised about the game we decided to play.

desc: To craft something is to make it using skill.
exam: She crafted the bookcase out of solid pine wood and then painted it.

desc: A crook is someone who is not honest or who commits crimes.
exam: The manager was arrested by the police for being a crook.

desc: Currency is the form of money used in a certain place.
exam: Elizabeth had to exchange her dollars for foreign currency.

desc: An enigma is someone or something that is mysterious or hard to understand.
exam: The theft of the paintings is an enigma to the investigators.

desc: When people or things are fragile, they are not strong and can be damaged easily.
exam: The fragile glassware was carefully packed into boxes.

desc: A hybrid is a mixture of different things or styles.
exam: In Greek mythology, a centaur is a hybrid of a man and a horse.

desc: Innocence is a lack of experience of difficult or complex things in life.
exam: Everyone who met her found her innocence to be charming.

desc: To merge two things is to combine them into one whole thing.
exam: The storm clouds merged into one large menacing cloud that filled the sky.

desc: When something is moderate, it is not too big or too small in size or amount.
exam: It takes a moderate amount of patience to be around small children all day.

desc: To overwhelm is to exist in such a large amount that someone cannot deal with it.
exam: The amount of homework her teacher assigned has overwhelmed her.

desc: A perception of a situation is a way of thinking about it or understanding it.
exam: Since he couldn’t see, his perception of life was much different than mine.

desc: A reunion is the meeting of people or things that have been separated.
exam: Every summer we have a family reunion at the lake.

desc: To rig something means to dishonestly arrange it.
exam: The bad politician rigged the election so that he would win.

desc: A shiver is a shaking movement the body makes when someone is cold or scared.
exam: I got shivers on my way home because it was so cold.

desc: When someone is sociable, they are friendly.
exam: Many of my good friends are sociable, but I am shy.

desc: When someone is talkative, they talk a lot.
exam: My aunt is very talkative whenever she is on the phone.

desc: To tow something is to pull it.
exam: The truck was towing a trailer behind it.

desc: To tramp is to put your feet down in a loud, heavy way as you walk.
exam: The baby tramped across the floor as he was learning to walk.
